abstracts.cdata!:
Overall, the outcome of the project was
            satisfactory. Despite the failure in achieving the
            pedagogical aspects, the success of the educational quality
            improvement objectives, largely compensated this
            shortcoming. Improvements were attained in secondary
            teachers training, coupled with a high degree of approval in
            textbooks selection. The provision of in-service training
            workshops, served as a tool to raise the pedagogical skills
            level, and the project was instrumental in supporting the
            decentralization of education management, and, successful in
            strengthening the institutional capacity of the Ministry of
            Education, Youth and Sports. The major lessons learned
            indicate that: 1) capacity building, increases resource
            efficiency, developing expertise within government agencies,
            and improving the project operation and management; 2)
            quality measures require the development of baseline and
            impact indicators for outcome monitoring; it is important to
            note that same were not included in the project design; 3)
            the proper coordination of activities among
            agencies/entities could ensure greater efficiency during
            project implementation; 4) the curriculum unification,
            particularly in dual-language instruction systems, should be
            realistic; thus the project succeeded with common objectives
            for the short-term; and, 5) stronger donor partnerships
            should be emphasized, designed to be manageable and ease
            coordination activities.
